records.Name: ICS spreading
records.clm__Code__c:
General scheme of
ICS spreading

  • Mouth and throat

    Medication:

    Low level of settling in guttur, 80–90% in inactive state

    Other ICS:

    Level of medication's settling in guttur is  25 times lower compared with budesonide (р<0,001);  12,5 times lower compared with fluticasone(р<0,001)

  • Lungs

    Medication:

    Activation in lungs

    High lipophilicity

    Large spreading volume

    Other ICS:

    Different level of deposition in lungs, from 10 to 50%

  • Liver

    Medication:

    Pronounced effect of primary passing

    High liver clirence

    Other ICS:

    Inactivation during primary passing

  • GIT

    Medication:

    Low percentage of swallowing substance

    Other ICS:

    50–90% is being swallowed

  • System circulation

    Medication:

    Less than 1%, of which 99% are connected with plasma proteins

    Low risk of side effects

    Other ICS:

    From 1 to 20% of active substance in system circulation, level of connection with palsma proteins is dissimilar

1. Nave R et al, Clin Pharmacokinet 2004;43:479-486  2. Affrime MB et al, J Clin Pharmacol 2000;40:1227-1236  3. Ryrfeldt A et al, Eur J Respir Dis 1982;122(suppl):86-95  4. Rohatagi S et al,. J Clin Pharmacol 1996;36:938-941  5. Martin LE et al, Postgrad Med J 1975;51:11-20 6. Kai Richter et al Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, 2005;45:146-152 7. R. Nave et al Pulmonary Pharmacology & Therapeutics 18 (2005)390–396

Absorbtion
Activation
Receptor binding
DNA transcription
Reversible binding

Due to high lipophilicity the medication absorbs quickly

The medication is being activated by lung esterases

The medication has high GCS affinity

The medication reversively binds to lipids

The influence on the DNA transcription provides significant antiinflammatory effect

Esterases

GC-receptors

Cell membrane

Lipids

DNA

The medication activates antiinflammatory genes

The medication blocks proinflammatory genes transcription
